instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7151: What is R7151? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7152: What is R7152? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
I have a Macbook Pro 13" Retina 2015 (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) with a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board. It got water damage and I got if for free from work to play around with.
I've watched many of Louises videos and I'm very interested to learn board repair as a hobby.

I get a green light (turns orange after a couple seconds) when connecting power. If I put my multimeter to VDC and measure <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on F7140 it fluctuate from 3.2V to 11-12V with 5 seconds-isch between the highs and lows.

If I put it in diode mode (with no power to the board) and put the red probe on ground and black on F7140 I get 132 on the multimeter on both sides of the fuse.
I measured the same on F7700 and got 127 on both sides. I don't know if this is to any help since I don't have a know good value for this.

What can make it fluctuate like that? I've never heard Louise mention anything like that in the videos I've watched.
Or is it my multimeter? It's a cheap ass multimeter for like $15 that I borrowed from my step dad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message: Resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of the ISL? Where was the original corrosion?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
$10 should be good too.
Is not multimeter problem; you have a problem on the board.
Check if voltage on big coils fluctuate too.

Also try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
No Title

[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 43542"]Resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of the ISL? Where was the original corrosion? [/QUOTE]

Is the ISL the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> or <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>?
If I look in the schematics I only find these two with the name ISL that have up to 28 pins.
And by 17/18 and 27/28 do you mean resistance between 17 and 18 or 17 and 27?

My probes on my multimeter are two thick so can't seem to get an accurate reading. I tried to file them down but the only "accurate" reading I could get was from 17-27 on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and it was somewhere around 10.6 Kohm

I'm gonna get some new probes tomorrow that will let me test this properly.

I've attached two pictures where the corrosion was. There might have been small drops outside the marked area.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 43557"]$10 should be good too.
Is not multimeter problem; you have a problem on the board.
Check if voltage on big coils fluctuate too.

Also try to start in SMC bypass mode.[/QUOTE]

By big coils do you mean the inductors?
I'm kind of new to this so sorry if I ask dumb questions.

I measured the voltage on L7130 and it fluctuate the same between 3.2-11V
L7520: 0-5V
L1295: 0-1V

I can't seem to find out how to start in SMC bypass though but I have done a SMC reset and that didn't do anything.

I just noticed that if I have the battery connected at the same time as the powe cable it stops fluctuating and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 10.6V
I only tried this when putting it back in the chassi to try restting the SMC.

Does this narrow it down?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
Does it start with both charger and battery connected?
You only need board, charger and battery.
Just connect an USB mouse and see if gets light.

You can measure direct on the caps close to pins 17/18 and 27/28; <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>, of course.
Be sure there are good traces to ISL...

Press power button, connect charger and maintain pressing 5-10s (SMC bypass).

BTW, search for "fine multimeter probe".

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 43572"]Does it start with both charger and battery connected?
You only need board, charger and battery.
Just connect an USB mouse and see if gets light.

You can measure direct on the caps close to pins 17/18 and 27/28; <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>, of course.
Be sure there are good traces to ISL...

Press power button, connect charger and maintain pressing 5-10s (SMC bypass).

BTW, search for "fine multimeter probe".[/QUOTE]

If I do this correctly I get 5.2 Kohms on 17/18 and on 27/28 I get 20 ohms
I measured 17/18 on <CAPACITOR>C7150</CAPACITOR> and 27/28 on <CAPACITOR>C7120</CAPACITOR> if that is correct.

I plugged in the mouse and it lights up both when power+battery is connected and also lights up when only power or only battery connected. When only battery was connected it took a couple of seconds for it to light up.

Also tried SMC bypass but it wouldn't boot.
I never get any fanspin.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
"If I do this correctly I get 5.2 Kohms on 17/18"
There is your problem; you should get 3 ohms aprox!
Check <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/52 ans their traces to <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>.

"I never get any fanspin."
Fan will start after looong time on this machine; CPU must get hot first.

BTW, do NOT quote an entire post from few cm above...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
Ok so your issue is 17/18. One of a few things is true:
1. <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> and/or <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> are blown.
2. <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> is blown (less likely)
3. The traces between <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/2 and the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> are bad or the traces between <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/2 and <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> is blown

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
Ah thanks.
I can't find <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> in boardview though. I can find <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> and that is exactly where the corrosion happened.
I'm at work at the moment but I will check this when I get home tonight.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
"Check <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/52 ans their traces to <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>.
----------
I can't find <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>"
Sorry, I should write <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR>/52...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message: ah great, now I found them in boardview. I will post here tonight with my findings.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> 2.4 ohm
<RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> 5.8 Kohm

So I'm guessing <RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> is shorted to ground/faulty here?

When trying to measure <RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> I just touched <CAPACITOR>C7150</CAPACITOR> and it broke of. So I will need to get replacements for at least <RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7150</CAPACITOR>

Is it possible to order these parts online somewhere like Mouser or do I have to get a donor board for these parts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message: Just replace them from a donor board so much easier. Replace <RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7150</CAPACITOR> and this should be fine would be my guess

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7150</CAPACITOR> is not critical...
You can test without it and should work.
However, is better to solder it, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
Thanks. I just ordered a donor board.
Will replacing these components fix the fluctuating voltage when the battery is not connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message: Yes it should. Your current sensing circuit (pins 17/18) being damaged is very likely causing your issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
You can also put tiny wires in place of <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR>/52.
It will work with 0 ohm in both places...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
Great. Thank you for all you help.
I guess I can try to put wires there if it will work. Is it magnet wire that I should use or could I use any copper wire for this since it only a replacement for a component?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
Doesn't matter.
Use as tiny as permit an easy job...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Water damage, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuate
threads.message:
I bought a soldering iron and a hot air station to try and put wires in place of <RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR>. I ended up screwing up <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> with the soldering iron and couldn't get the pins to connect to the board again and then I fucked up the pads on <RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> as well. The hot air station couldn't even get a resistor of the board so I guess it was a cheap piece of crap.

Thank you for all you help. To bad I suck at soldering so I couldn't fix it.
